# How to Download Rufus 3.4 Portable Bootable USB Tool for Linux, Windows 7, 8, 10
 
Rufus is a free and open-source software that allows you to create bootable USB drives from ISO files. You can use Rufus to install various operating systems such as Linux, Windows 7, 8, 10 and more on your computer or laptop. Rufus is also portable, which means you can run it from any USB drive without installing it on your system.

In this article, we will show you how to download Rufus 3.4 portable bootable USB tool for Linux, Windows 7, 8, 10 and how to use it to create bootable USB drives.
 
## How to Download Rufus 3.4 Portable Bootable USB Tool
 
To download Rufus 3.4 portable bootable USB tool, you need to visit the official website of Rufus at [https://rufus.ie/](https://rufus.ie/). On the homepage, you will see a download section where you can choose the version of Rufus you want to download. For this article, we will download the portable version of Rufus 3.4 which is compatible with Windows XP or later.
 
Click on the link that says "Rufus 3.4 Portable" and save the file to your USB drive or any location on your computer. The file size is about 1 MB and it will take a few seconds to download.
 
## How to Use Rufus 3.4 Portable Bootable USB Tool
 
Once you have downloaded Rufus 3.4 portable bootable USB tool, you can run it by double-clicking on the file or right-clicking on it and choosing "Run as administrator". You will see a user interface like this:
 ![Rufus user interface](https://i.imgur.com/0wZJFyf.png) 
To use Rufus 3.4 portable bootable USB tool, you need to have an ISO file of the operating system you want to install and a USB drive with enough space to store the ISO file. You also need to backup any important data on your USB drive as Rufus will erase everything on it.
 
Follow these steps to create a bootable USB drive using Rufus:
 
1. Insert your USB drive into your computer and make sure it is detected by Rufus.
2. Select your USB drive from the "Device" dropdown menu.
3. Select the "Disk or ISO image" option from the "Boot selection" dropdown menu and click on the "SELECT" button to browse for your ISO file.
4. Select your ISO file and click on "Open". Rufus will automatically detect the best settings for your ISO file such as partition scheme, file system and cluster size.
5. If you want to change any settings, you can do so by clicking on the icons next to each option. For example, you can change the volume label, add a persistent partition or check for bad blocks.
6. When you are ready, click on the "START" button to begin the process of creating a bootable USB drive.
7. Rufus will ask you to confirm that you want to erase all data on your USB drive. Click on "OK" to proceed.
8. Rufus will then copy the ISO file to your USB drive and make it bootable. This may take several minutes depending on the size of your ISO file and the speed of your USB drive.
9. When Rufus is done, you will see a message that says "READY". You can now close Rufus and safely remove your USB drive from your computer.
10. You can now use your bootable USB drive to install Linux, Windows 7, 8, 10 or any other operating system on your computer or laptop by changing the boot order in your BIOS settings.
